entry.title: My AI Experience Sharing ‚Äì Setting up Joule for the S/4HANA Public Edition (Pt B:Joule Installation)
entry.content:
Introduction

Now Artificial Intelligence (AI) is on every professional‚Äôs mind. Everybody wants to be on the bandwagon.  I plan to write a series of blogs on this topic under a big umbrella ‚ÄúMy AI Experience Sharing‚Äù.  This is the first mini-series: setting up Joule for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. 

I purposely delayed my action on setting up a Joule to wait for the dust settling down during the Early Adopter phase. The intention paid off but still won‚Äôt give me a free pass üòâ. There are five credible references available as listed in the Reference section, but none of them give you a good explanation on Why, especially on What in a critical step with a readable picture when you desperately need a hint.  To help all the people like me, this blog will focus on explaining those steps, what to enter, and possible mistakes to avoid. 

Note 1: The content here is drawn from my direct experience from setting up Joule for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (more than five times and still counting). It might be true for other SAP solutions but only use that as a reference so that I don‚Äôt feel the pressure of entire SAP world on my shoulder üòÅ.

Note 2: Since there are a lot of topics to discuss, I divided the mini-series into Part A Preparation,  Part B Joule Installation and Part C Deinstallation. 

Note 3: The systems I used in this mini-series are:

  • BTP Global Account: 2024-09 3SL Account
  • BTP Joule Subaccount: PSCC-AMER-3SL-PRD
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Production tenant G4X/100, http://myxxxxxxx.s4hana.cloud.sap/ 
  • Cloud Identity Services: Provisioned together with above BTP and Public Cloud tenants, xxxxxxxx.accounts.ondemand.com

Note 4: Considering some customers and consultants need to deinstall and reinstall Joule for many reasons like practicing the installation, correcting an unsuccessful installation, etc., I am adding a new blog Part C: Deinstallation here for your reference.

 

Ten Major Joule Installation Steps Explained

In this section, I am going to explain all ten Joule Installation Steps.  The hyperlink of each step gives a direct access to the document.

We can group Joule Installation Steps into four categories:

  • Step B.1: Run Joule Booster
  • Steps B.2 ‚Äì B.4: Validate the results of running Joule Booster, make some updates accordingly.
  • Steps B.5 ‚Äì B.9: Setup an infrastructure and provision/replicate users/groups from the Public Cloud to the Work Zone
  • Step B.10: Test your Joule

 

Step B.1 DC1: Run Booster in SAP BTP for Joule

Within SAP BTP, there is a concept called formation, which is a logical grouping of SAP systems, specifically designed for event sharing within a business scenario.  The Joule Booster groups four systems into one formation for the business scenario of Running Joule on the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: SAP Cloud Identity Services, SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP Build Work Zone, and Joule.  Refer to the picture in Step B.2.1 Check the Formation Created by the Joule Booster.

The Joule Booster is to automate the formation creation process, including communication related infrastructure. Here is the final Review page before executing the Joule Booster.

Review Page of the Joule Booster

Note: From April 9, 2025, our BTP colleagues made an improvement in the Joule Booster. Now there are two versions available, "Setting Up Joule (Internal Prod)" and "Setting Up Joule". The former one is for SAP internal setup usage, and later one is for customers and partners.  There are different entitlement requirements for each of them.  I waited one entitlement for weeks to run the "Setting Up Joule (Internal Prod)".  Hope this won‚Äôt be the case for you.

 

Step B.2 Post Booster Configuration

At the end of Discovery Center Establish a Unified Joule Instance and the beginning of Discovery Center Activate Joule with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, there are two very similar steps: Post Booster Configuration for the former, and Validate SAP BTP configuration after Joule Booster Execution for the later. Some work is redundant, but you need to follow Post Booster Configuration first, then Validate SAP BTP configuration after Joule Booster Execution.  Because there are critical steps in Post Booster Configuration to create NavigationService destination, etc. 

In one installation exercise, I tried to launch the Work Zone link in the Instances and Subscriptions, I got an error message: "Uh oh‚Ä¶We can‚Äôt seem to find the site that you‚Äôre looking for. Either the site doesn‚Äôt exist or it‚Äôs temporarily unavailable.‚Äù  The reason is that the system needs to use the Portal Service URL definition stored in the NavigationService destination to access https://portal-service.cfapps.eu12.hana.ondemand.com/resources/portal/sap/cf/pages/siteNotFound/siteNotFound.html. 

B.2.1 Check the Formation Created by the Joule Booster.

Within the Joule formation, all four systems should be included (shown in the picture of above).

The BTP Formation for the Joule Running on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

Depending on your business needs, you can add another SAP solution into it.  For example, if you add a SuccessFactors system here, both SuccessFactors and Public Cloud share the same Joule.

B.2.2 Check Joule Subscription and Destinations setup in BTP Subaccount

Joule subscription was created as part of the Joule Booster execution.  This step is to test a user can logon to the Joule application.  The URL is like this https://pscc-amer-3sl-prd-xxxxxxxx.eu12.sapdas.cloud.sap/. As you can see in this string, the first part is my subaccount name PSCC-AMER-3SL-PRD. The second part xxxxxxxx is the Joule‚Äôs system ID (partially).  The last part is the subdomain.  In the Post Booster Configuration, it was listed as ‚Äú4m8qi0do‚Äù. The last part indicates the data center is located in Europe (e12), and it is a Joule system (sapdas).

Note: when you launch the Joule application for the first time here, a new user with a cryptic ID is created (see the user discussion in Step B.3.2 Content Provider). That's another reason Step B.2 needs to be executed before B.3.

B.2.3 Check If Destinations Are Created Successfully

In Validate SAP BTP configuration after Joule Booster Execution, it lists six destinations.  In my case, only four destinations are created by the Joule Booster as shown in the picture.  There are no Navigation Service nor Runtime destinations there as described

  • Design Time Destination - (with _dt in the name)
  • Runtime Destinations (Not there)
  • Runtime Data (with _rt_data in the name)
  • Runtime Default (with _rt_default in the name)
  • S4HANA_PUB_SSO
  • Navigation Service (Not there yet. Wasn‚Äôt created automatically)

Four Destinations Created by the Joule Booster

B.2.4 Create NavigationService Destination

To complete this step, we need to use the Service Key created in the Step A.7 Create SAP Build Work Zone Instance and Subscription.  My NavigationSerivce definition is shown below as a reference.

NavigationService Properties

For your convenience, I am listing the entry mapping between Service Content Key and the NavigationService definition.

Work Zone Service Key File Content

Navigation Service Properties

Notes

 

Name: NavigationService

 
 

Type: HTTP

 
 

Description: can be anything

 
 

Proxy Type: Internet

 

‚Äúportal ‚Äì service‚Äù

URL

Including https://

 

Authentication: OAuth2UserTokenExchange

 

‚Äúclientid‚Äù

Client ID

 

‚Äúclientsecret‚Äù

Client Secret

 

‚Äúurl‚Äù

Token Service URL

Add /oauth/token toward the end of the string, with leading https://

 

After saving the destination, click on the button Check Connection.  I got an error 404 in the first time.  This indicates a web page cannot be found.

Error 404 when Checking Navigation Service Connection

There are two URL‚Äôs in the destination definition.  The first one is https://portal-service.cfapps.eu12.hana.ondemand.com.  When I enter it in a Web Browser, it returns 404 error:

               404 Not Found: Requested route ('portal-service.cfapps.eu12.hana.ondemand.com') does not exist.

This NavigationService is a mystery to me.  In the Solution Architecture diagram (see the beginning of the Part A Preparation Blog), there is a Navigation Target Mapping within the BTP box.  It is used by the Work Zone to fetch roles and available navigational targets, kind of like a look up table. Therefore you don't execute this connection directly. 

At the beginning of Step B.2, I presented an error message due to the absence of NavationService destination. 

The second URL is the Token Service URL. That one works when posting directly in a Web Browser.

B.2.5 Update Application Configuration in SAP Cloud Identity Authentication Service

This step is to verify two applications created by the Joule Booster das-ias and Document Grounding have the same Conditional Authentication setting.

In below figure, although there is no subaccount name as part of the das-ias application, but the number 2199220a appears in all three applications: das-ias, Document Grounding, and SAP BTP subaccount PSCC-AMER-3SL-PRD. I can comfortably conclude that applications das-ias and Document Grounding are Joule related for my subaccount PSCC-AMER-3SL-PRD.

Three Joule Related Applications in the SAP CIS

All three applications have the same Conditional Authentication setting using Identity Authentication. Joule Booster did a good job!

B.2.6 Update Trusted Domains Settings

This setting is also in the SAP CIS. We already completed it in Step A.6 Blog1: 7.2 Trust the Public Cloud Tenant Domain in SAP Cloud Identity Services.

 

Step B.3 DC2: Validate SAP BTP configuration after Joule Booster Execution

B.3.1 Check SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Destinations setup in BTP Subaccount

This step is the same as B.2.3 Check If Destinations Are Created Successfully.

B.3.2 Check Content Provider in the SAP Work Zone

The purpose of this step is to find out the name of the Work Zone Channel Content Provider which we will use for later (Step B.8).

In the BTP Cockpit -> Security -> Users, usually you can see a pair of users with the same Username but different Identity Provider.  For example, my name is listed twice: one with a temporary cryptic ID (also called IAS shadow user ID) and another with my email address.  The cryptic user ID is created/updated on the fly when you access the SAP Work Zone or Joule.  During Joule Setup, this cryptic ID is created in Step B.2.2 Check Joule Subscription and Destinations setup in BTP Subaccount when you launch the Joule application.  Its Identity Provider is the SAP Cloud ID Service or IAS.  My last Work Zone logon time is May 23. 

The email address username is used for logon to BTP tenant.   It uses the Default Identity Provider and shows May 27 because I logged on to the BTP on May 27.

Two Parallel Users in the BTP User List

There are six sub-steps listed in the document. I‚Äôd like to explain some of these steps:

Steps 1-3: The SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition is the new name for the SAP Launchpad service. So, you will still see the name of Launchpad here and there.  The reason of assigning the Launchpad_Admin role to the cryptic User ID is to prepare this user to access the SAP Build Work Zone as an administrator to read its Content Provider name.  Without this user role, your access to the Work Zone will be denied.

Step 5: This step is to logon to the Work Zone as an Administrator with your username and the password stored in the IAS. The user must have the Launchpad_Admin role assigned.

When you launch the Work Zone, pay attention to the URL: https://pscc-amer-3sl-prd-xxxxxxxx.dt.launchpad.cfapps.eu12.hana.ondemand.com/sites#Site-Directory.  It is in fact the URL in your Service Key file, and you entered it during NavigationService creation in Step B.2.4. 

Step 6: The Content Provider ID will be used in the SAP Cloud Identity Provisioning setup (Step B.9).  It will be part of many names I will point it out later.

 

Step B.4 DC2: Validate and Update S/4HANA Cloud Configuration after Joule Booster Execution

In the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the integration with other SAP solutions is predefined according to the scenarios, that includes the integration with the BTP. 

For each integration scenario, we have one specific Communication Arrangement defined, which in turn depends on the underlying Communication System.  One Communication System can support one or more Communication Arrangement(s), but not the other way around.  If you want two same type of Communication Arrangement integrates to two solutions, you need to create two different Communication Arrangements (different names but the same type) residing on two different Communication Systems.

Here are two Communication Arrangements for Joule setup:

  • SAP_COM_0647 for Launchpad Content Exposure to SAP BTP Integration
  • SAP_COM_0882 for SAP Digital Assistant Services

Since the Communication Arrangements are created by the Joule Booster, they all use cryptic ID instead of readable names. Sometimes you might have multiple of them. The easiest way to identify the right one is to check its creation/changing date when you run the Joule Booster.

The Joule Booster creates four Communication Systems. Two are used for the above two Communication Systems. The other two Communication Systems are not used by any Communication Arrangements.  I don‚Äôt know why Joule Booster creates them.  If you have an insight on them, please comment!

 

Step B.5 DC2: Configure S/4HANA Cloud for User Replication with Identity Provisioning Service

Steps B.5 though B.9 are for provisioning users and roles from the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to the SAP Work Zone instance.  This is very similar as we provision users from the IAS to the Central Business Configuration in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition as I discussed in my blog Deep Dive into the CBC User Authentication and Authorization Concept.

Let me give a quick explanation (referring below figure). SAP Work Zone is a service running on the SAP BTP.  It does not create users and assign user roles within itself. However, when you access Joule (through Work Zone), you are still limited to those apps you have authorizations to access. This is achieved by doing an authorization check within the Work Zone.

Concept of User/Group Provisioning for the SAP Work Zone

To provision users and corresponding roles from the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, we need to prepare a user provisioning infrastructure manually here.  In comparison, the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition has this infrastructure provisioned by the operations team during system provisioning.

Step B.5 is to set up the Identity Provisioning infrastructure, namely the Communication Arrangement and the Communication System. 

Take a note of the newly created Inbound Communication User, including the username and the password. We will use them in Step B.7.  If this Communication User is locked after multiple logon failures, you won‚Äôt be able to provision users/groups to Work Zone again, for example, after you add new users and add/remove user roles.

 

Step B.6 DC2: Update Content Security Policy Settings in S/4HANA Cloud

This step is to add the URL of the Joule application to the Trusted Sites list of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition via application Manage Content Security Policy.  This way the Joule can run as an add-on to the Public Cloud and access all of its data and applications.

You can obtain your Joule application URL by going to BTP ÔÉ† Your Subaccount ÔÉ† Services ÔÉ† Instances and Subscriptions ÔÉ† Subscriptions ÔÉ† Application ÔÉ† Clicking on the Joule hyperlink.

Add the Joule URL to the Trusted Site List

 

Step B.7 DC2: Configure Identity Provisioning Service for User Replication to Work Zone

This Step is to make Identity Provisioning Service working.  You do the following:

  • Configure SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition as a Source System in Identity Provisioning
  • Configure SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition as a Target System in Identity Provisioning

The following figure displays The SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Cloud as a New Source System in the SAP CIS.  The communication user is that Inbound Communication User created in Step B.4.   The newly created Source System is S4-myxxxxx-source-joule. 

The SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Cloud as a New Source System in the SAP CIS

When you create a new Target System, make sure your Source System is S4-myxxxxx-source-joule, the one you just created as shown below.  They work in tandem.

The Work Zone as a New Target System in the SAP CIS

Since the Target System is the Work Zone, we need to use the user information stored in Work Zone instance of the BTP (referring Step A.7).

If you don‚Äôt have the Service Key file, follow this path: BTP -> Your Subaccount -> Services -> Instances and Subscriptions -> Instances -> Instance  -> Your Work Zone Instance -> Service Keys, download the Service Key file.

The Discovery Zone has a good screenshot to map the Target System creation window and the Service Key file content.  If the picture is too blurry, download it, then enlarge it to be readable!!! It is my tip of the day üòâ.

 

Step B.8 DC2: Provision Users and Groups from S/4HANA Cloud to Work Zone

After above Steps B.5 ‚Äì B.7, we are ready to provision user and group information from the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Source System) to the Work Zone instance (Target System).  This step uses the Identity Provision Service (IPS) function within the SAP CIS.

 

Step B.9 DC2: Validate User Provisioning in SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition

Besides checking the Provisioning Log in Step B.8, you can also check the results of this provisioning work by doing the following: BTP  -> Your Subaccount  -> Services  -> Instances and Subscriptions  -> Subscriptions  -> Application  -> clicking the hyperlink of SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition.  The Work Zone Site Manage window is launched.

From Content Manager, you can see all the groups provisioned.  The covered text string in the ID Column is the Content Provider ID we explored in above Step B.3.  For example, the ID ~sap.start.xxxxyyy_SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR indicates the role SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR is from Content Provider xxxxyyy. 

Viewing the Provisioned User Roles/Groups in the Work Zone Content Manager

If you click on the ID ~sap.start.xxxxyyy_SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR, it reveals the applications assigned to this Role ID.

Apps Assigned to the Role ID ~sap.start.xxxxyyy_SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR

By clicking on the Settings  -> Identity Provisioning, we can see the individual user information.  The covered text string in the Role ID Column or the Provider ID Column is the Work Zone Content Provider ID we explored in Step B.3.  In other words, these roles are effective in the mentioned Work Zone.

Viewing the Individual User and the Assigned Groups in the Settings -> Identity Provisioning

These two roles match what I have in the Public Cloud as shown below.

Two Business Roles Assigned to My Account

 

Step B.10 Test Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud

This is an exciting step of your entire setup journey.

As you can see from my above screens, I only have two Administrator authorizations in this setup. When I open the Joule, it suggests the apps based on my role, such as ‚ÄúFind Security Audit Log Apps‚Äù. After I click on it, it did the job for me.

Joule‚Äôs Suggestion base on My User Roles

 

Joule Helped Me to Open the Security Audit Log

There are two possible issues you might face:

  1. You don‚Äôt see the Joule icon after you setup Joule for the first time. This happens quite often. Don‚Äôt worry and it might be caused by old caches in your Web Browser. Try to open an Incognico or Private window and launch your SAP S/4HANA Cloud. If the Joule icon is there, you are good. You can delete old caches in your regular web browser.
  2. You cannot display the Sales Order list in the Joule. Most probably you don‚Äôt have the right authorizations.  You should fail at launching any sales order related apps as well as shown below.  Give yourself the right user roles, and re-provision the users from S/4HANA Cloud to the Work Zone as described in Step B.8.

Failed to ‚ÄúShow Sales Orders‚Äù due to Authorization Limit to the User

 

Conclusion

In this blog, I explained reasons and catches of all the steps outlined in the Discovery Center 1 Establish a Unified Joule Instance and Discovery Center 2 Activate Joule with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, focusing on the steps running the Joule Booster and post-processes. By following some tips outlined, I hope you can reach your end zone with no or less troubles.

 

References

  1. Blog 1: Joule ‚Äì End-to-End Setup Guide (for all Line of Business) Unified Approach
  2. Blog 2: Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Setup Guide
  3. Discovery Center 1: Establish a Unified Joule Instance
  4. Discovery Center 2: Activate Joule with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  5. SAP Help: Joule onboarding guide
  6. My Blog: My AI Experience Sharing ‚Äì Setting up Joule for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Part A Preparation)
  7. My Blog: My AI Experience Sharing ‚Äì Setting up Joule for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Part B Joule Installation)
  8. This Blog: My AI Experience Sharing ‚Äì Setting up Joule for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Part C Joule Deinstallation)

entry.title: What‚Äôs New in SAP Build: Highlights from SAP Sapphire 2025
entry.content:
As the SAP Sapphire 2025 global keynote outlined, this year's focus was clear: AI, applications, and data. SAP Build continues to evolve in alignment with these themes, helping organizations efficiently build, automate, and extend their business processes and applications.

Here's a roundup of Sapphire's key SAP Build announcements and innovations to watch this year.

Joule Studio: Intelligent AI Agents and Skills Builder

Joule Studio Capabilities

SAP unveiled Joule Studio, a new environment within SAP Build that helps you create, deploy, and manage AI agents and custom skills. With Joule Studio, teams can enrich Joule with company-specific skills and intelligent agents that work across SAP and third-party systems. Joule Studio brings two powerful capabilities:

  • Joule Skills: Design modular, reusable skills that can be invoked during conversations. These skills can trigger actions, pull data, and orchestrate SAP Build components like workflows, automations, or apps.
  • AI Agents: Go beyond skills by building full-fledged AI agents that dynamically execute business tasks using reasoning capabilities. These agents use business context, data from SAP systems, and large language models to adapt to user needs.

Joule Studio will be available by the end of Q2 2025, with Agent Builder capabilities expected in Q4 2025.

Early adopters like Sovanta, an SAP partner, already use Joule Studio to enhance customer service. Sovanta significantly streamlined support processes and accelerated ticket resolution by integrating conversational skills with SAP systems.

Another early adopter, Pricefx - a global leader in cloud-based pricing software - is using Joule Studio to bring AI-driven intelligence into their solution. By developing an Agentic AI copilot, they aim to deliver contextual, business-aware guidance that enhances pricing decisions for their customers.

Interested in learning more? Register for the webcast: Meet Joule Studio: Drive Innovation with AI Agents & Joule Skills.

New AI Capabilities for Business Users and Developers

  • SAP Build Work Zone + Joule: Employees can now use Joule to find relevant apps, tasks, and documents faster. It can summarize or generate content based on your business data, saving time and boosting productivity.

Joule in SAP Build Work Zone

  • AI-Enhanced ABAP Development: Developers migrating to SAP Cloud ERP can use AI to convert custom ECC code into ABAP Cloud standards. This feature simplifies modernization efforts while ensuring code quality and compliance.

These capabilities are expected in Q3 2025.

 Expanded SAP Build Capabilities

SAP Build continues to grow as a unified platform with:

  • Extensibility Wizard for SAP Business Suite: A guided wizard that helps you build side-by-side extensions with the proper context, faster. SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP SuccessFactors support is planned for release in H2 of 2025.

Extensibility Wizard in SAP Business Suite

Watch Sapphire Customer Session: Extending SAP S/4HANA Cloud with SAP Build at OGE: Open Grid Europe used SAP Build to extend SAP S/4HANA Cloud‚Äîboosting onboarding efficiency by 50% and reducing invoicing time by 20%.

Watch Sapphire Solution Demo: Extend SAP S/4HANA Cloud: SAP Build application development and automation. Discover how to rapidly personalize and extend SAP S/4HANA Cloud while maintaining a clean core.

  • SAP Business Data Cloud Integration: Planned for Q4 2025, SAP Build will offer deep integration with SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) via CAP. Developers can consume and expose data products using virtual tables in SAP HANA Cloud, accelerating the development of insight-rich apps while reducing manual integration work. This improves data consistency and supports scalable, compliant development.
  • Event-Driven Applications: SAP Build, in combination with SAP Integration Suite and CAP, will support event-based interactions across systems. General availability is expected in H2 2025.

Simplified Pricing and Packaging

  • SAP Build offers a unified pricing model that combines app development, automation, and workspaces under a single entitlement. This simplifies adoption, reduces licensing complexity, and allows teams to build and extend at their own pace. Learn more in this blog post.

Thanks for reading! Which SAP Build innovation are you most excited about? Let us know - and don't miss these key resources from SAP Sapphire 2025:

  • Watch Sapphire Global Keynote: Your Best. Made Real. No Matter What Lies Ahead
  • Read SAP Sapphire 2025 Innovation Guide
  • Visit the Session Catalog with On-Demand Sessions

entry.title: Introducing SAPUI5 Version Preview in SAP Build Work Zone
entry.content:
SAPUI5 is a cornerstone of SAP's user interface technology, providing a robust framework for building responsive and enterprise-ready web applications. Regular updates to SAPUI5 bring innovative features and critical bug fixes, ensuring that applications remain modern and efficient. Until now, the latest SAPUI5 versions were automatically adopted in production environments, which limited opportunities for early evaluation ahead of deployment.

Recognizing the need for controlled testing of SAPUI5 updates, we have introduced a new feature that allows administrators to preview upcoming SAPUI5 versions in non-productive environments within SAP Build Work Zone. This capability was developed in response to customer feedback, aiming to provide a controlled environment for evaluating SAPUI5 updates in SAP Build Work Zone, thereby avoiding immediate changes in production environments.

What's New: SAPUI5 Version Preview Feature in SAP Build Work Zone

The new "Preview SAPUI5 Latest Version" feature empowers administrators to test upcoming SAPUI5 versions in designated non-productive environments within SAP Build Work Zone. This proactive approach allows customers to explore upcoming updates in a controlled setting, supporting a smoother and more predictable transition to production environments.

This feature is available in SAP Build Work Zone, advanced and standard edition and SAP SuccessFactors Work Zone.

Key Benefits:

This feature offers several advantages. Administrators can gain early access to the Release to Customer (RTC) version of SAPUI5. They have two weeks before its general availability, allowing ample time for testing. By enabling the preview setting on specific non-productive sites, they can assess compatibility and performance with the upcoming version. This controlled testing environment helps identify and address potential issues, reducing the likelihood of disruptions in production. After the two-week preview period, the RTC version becomes the default, aligning all sites with the latest stable release.

How it works ‚Äì step by step

1. Enable Preview:

In the site editor, administrators can activate the "Preview SAPUI5 Latest Version" setting for selected non-productive sites.

Toggle turned off in site settings

Toggle turned on in site settings

Warning message while saving the changes 

Site preview on and further information

Site directory with a site where preview is turned on

2. Testing Period

The designated sites will consume the RTC version of SAPUI5 for a two-week period, during which thorough testing and validation can be conducted.

To enable this in SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition, customers can create a dedicated site in their existing PROD or PRE-PROD sub-accounts (or QA, if preferred), there is no need to create a new sub-account. The relevant content can be transported to this test site, where the preview option for SAPUI5 can then be enabled. In SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition, customer must setup a new sub-account (pre-prod) to use the UI5 preview feature.

3. Adjustment Option

If needed during the preview period, administrators can turn off the preview setting to revert the site back to the previously active version.

4. Automatic Update

After the two-week period, the RTC version becomes the default version for all sites, ensuring consistency across environments.

SAPUI5 versions

SAPUI5 provides new versions regularly to deliver innovative features and also to provide patches with bug fixes. See What's New in SAPUI5 and the SAPUI5 What's New Viewer to learn about the new features and Versioning and Maintenance of SAPUI5 to understand the versioning concept. A new version is consumed by default by SAP BTP services like SAP Build Work Zone to have a solid basis for new capabilities and an up-to-date user experience.

Approximately 2 weeks before a new version is consumed by SAP cloud solutions, it is released to customers (RTC). In this timeframe you may now test a new version with SAP Build Work Zone. Learn about the planned SAPUI5 versions with their planned RTC date in SAP Note 3504933.

Learn More! 

Important references:

  • See the planned SAPUI5 versions with their planned release date in SAP Note 3504933.
  • See the released SAPUI5 versions in SAPUI5 Versions Maintenance Status.

For more insights into SAPUI5 and SAP Build Work Zone:

  • Explore the SAPUI5: What's New and When Is It Coming? blog post on the SAP Community
  • SAP Build Work Zone on: sap.com / SAP Community
  • SAP Application Development and Automation Community Group

entry.title: Mastering SBPA Approvals : A Deep Dive into Wait Steps, Script Tasks, and API Integrations , Part 2
entry.content:
In our previous blog post, "Mastering Complex Approvals: A Deep Dive into Wait Steps, Script Tasks, and API Integrations," my colleague & SAP Mentor @mohit_bansal3  tackled a common but challenging business requirement: the "all-or-nothing" approval process.

Part 1 - Mastering Complex SBPA Approvals : A Deep Dive into Wait Steps, Script Tasks, and API Integrations

Part 2 : Current Blog : Demonstration with Complete end to end testing 

We explored how SAP Build Process Automation, leveraging features like Wait Steps with API Triggering and workflow context updates via API, can handle scenarios where multiple approvals are needed simultaneously, and a single rejection stops the entire workflow.

We walked through a procurement example where both Department Managers and the Finance Department had to unanimously approve a request before it could proceed.

Now, in this second blog, we will demonstrate the step-by-step testing process for the solution we developed. This will allow you to understand the entire development flow more deeply, from concept to validation. Let's dive into the testing for the previous blog's implementation!

Handling Approval Outcomes: Positive and Negative Scenarios

The "All-or-Nothing" Positive Scenario : Lets Start the complete Testing Process

Let's first explore the "positive scenario," where every approver gives their stamp of approval. In this ideal outcome, once all required approvals are secured, the main workflow successfully completes its designated task. This seamless progression is the goal of our "All-or-Nothing" design, ensuring that every necessary check is performed before finalization.

Approval Process Triggering
As you know from our previous blog, for demonstration purposes, we created a simple form within SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA). 

 

Main process upon submission of request: Context and log  

You'll notice two approvers listed, which will initiate two parallel workflows. We covered the specifics of these parallel workflows in a previous blog post. The determination of these approvers can come from a decision table or your own custom logic.

The key takeaway here is that we've dynamically fetched two approvers, demonstrating the adaptable nature of this step.  it can handle any number of approvers.

 

 

Dynamically Triggering Secondary Workflows

We're now kicking off secondary workflows dynamically, and the number of these workflows depends entirely on the number of approvers.

For our current scenario, since we have two approvers, this process will trigger two parallel secondary workflows.

Each of these workflows will then send an individual approval request directly to each approver's My Inbox.

Dynamically Secondary Workflow Triggered via API

My Inbox View
Here's a quick look at My Inbox. For this demonstration, we've assigned the same approver.

That's why you see two work items in this approver's inbox. In a real-world scenario, these would be two separate workflow approval items, each in the respective approver's inbox.

Crucially, the main workflow won't complete until both approvals are in.

 

Workflow Progress After First Approval
The screenshot below shows the workflow log after the first approver has taken action. As you can see, the workflow isn't complete yet; it's waiting for the second secondary workflow to be actioned.

The main workflow will only move forward once both approvals are done.

But before we get ahead of ourselves, let's examine the workflow log immediately after that initial approvals.

 

Updating the Main Workflow Context after each approval:  SBPA API used as action
We'll be updating the main workflow's context after each approval and then comparing it against the total required count.

Here's a quick glimpse of what happens to the workflow context once the first approval is complete.

You can see the "donecount" increasing, which we'll use to compare against the total number of approvals needed.

We achieve this by updating the main workflow via its API, a process we've already covered in a previous blog post.

 

The Final Approval and Workflow Completion
Now, let's go a step deeper and understand the flow when the second, and final, approver takes action.

Once they approve, you'll see that the secondary workflow also completes, which then triggers the wait step in the main workflow.

This wait step is triggered via an API, a process we covered in detail in a previous blog post.

Understanding this particular use case of the wait step with an API is a critical aspect of this blog's core message.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Workflow Context After All Approvals
Now, let's carefully examine how the workflow context gets updated once all approvals are complete.

This is the crucial step that triggers the wait step and allows our main workflow to proceed.

In this scenario, the "donecount" becomes equal to the total number of required approvals, which in turn triggers the wait step API.

 

Handling Approval Outcomes: Positive and Negative Scenarios

so far We've explored the "positive scenario," where all approvers green-light the requests, leading to the main workflow's successful completion.

But what happens when an approver rejects a request?

Imagine a scenario where just one approver rejects. In such a case, the entire workflow must be rejected. My colleague, Mohit Bansal, detailed the design considerations for this rejection scenario in a previous blog post, so from a testing perspective, the approach remains similar.

However, in a rejection scenario, we need to take crucial additional steps:

  • Call the workflow cancel API: This immediately stops the main workflow.
  • Cancel any remaining open instances of secondary workflows: This is critical for designing a robust, production-ready complex workflow. Without canceling these, you could have orphaned workflow instances consuming resources or causing confusion.

     

  • Here's a quick look at how the system responds when any approver rejects: the main workflow is canceled, and all remaining open secondary workflow instances are also terminated.

We hope you enjoyed our blog series! We dove deep into complex workflow approval scenarios, exploring how to effectively leverage wait steps and workflow APIs to achieve robust "all-or-nothing" approval processes.

Please feel free to leave comments and share your thoughts. A big thank you to my colleague @mohit_bansal3  for his contributions, and stay tuned for more blogs on the latest innovations in this area!

Regards,

Adwait Fadnavis

entry.title: Support of SAP Build Work Zone, advanced and much more: SAP Mobile Start V2.2 & 2.3 - Release Update
entry.content:
In this blog, I will introduce the new features that we have released so far in 2025, with version V2.2 and our latest version V2.3.
When SAP Mobile Start got launched in August 2021, the app got automatically provisioned with SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition. In 2023, we added SAP Start and with the release V.2.2, SAP Mobile Start also connects to SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition.

When using SAP Mobile Start with SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition, you can now access your advanced edition content, like Workspaces or Feed Updates. As with the standard edition, your native and web apps are available within the Apps Screen of SAP Mobile Start, as well as in your Favorites Section on the Start Screen, based on your individual selection. This allows you direct and fast access to your business content while being mobile. 
What about the SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition tasks and notifications? If you have set up the Alert Notification Service and SAP Task Center Service, then you find them next to your business tasks and situations in the To-Do sections and in the Notification Center of SAP Mobile Start.

Screenshot: Notification Center with advanced edition notifications

We are looking forward to seeing many SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition and SAP SuccessFactors Work Zone customers to onboard to SAP Mobile Start, as it is automatically available if the SAP Mobile Start ‚Äútoggle‚Äù is enabled in the Site Manager.

Remark: SAP Mobile Start is not the successor app for the SAP Build Work Zone Advanced mobile app. SAP Mobile Start focuses on providing users easy access to their applications and business workflows. The app is deeply integrated into the device OS and provides native push notifications and widgets to ensure a best-in-class user experience. The SAP Build Work Zone Advanced mobile app focuses more on the collaboration aspects. Users can use both apps in parallel. Please also see our respective knowledge base article for further details. 

Besides seeing your latest open To-Dos in SAP Mobile Start, you can now also see your completed To-Dos. Just tap the ‚ÄúCompleted‚Äù filter button on the To-Do Screen and you will get your completed to-dos from the last six months right on the To-Dos Screen. You can also search across all open and completed to-dos via the search function.

Screenshot: Completed To-Dos

My favorite new feature is the site switch that is available with V2.3. This feature allows you to directly switch between SAP Build Work Zone sites. This is very helpful for IT teams but also for business users who work with multiple SAP Build Work Zone instances. Instead of always having to go through the complete onboarding process, the app offers you a list of recently used sites and you can just pick the one you need. Outdated sites can be deleted from your list with an easy swipe to the left. I am sure that you will love this feature.

Screenshots: Site Switch

Another nice enhancement comes for the news tiles. With the latest release of SAP Mobile Start, your news tile can also include news images. Furthermore, news feeds that require authentication are supported as well with the latest release. You just need to maintain the authenticated URL in the tile news property field ‚Äúmobilestart.feedUrl‚Äù in the site manager. Please have a look at our SAP Help documentation for details.

Screenshots: News with Image

You can now see the source system name on the app tiles with the latest release, what is very helpful if you have for instance connected multiple SAP S/4HANA systems to SAP Build Work Zone. The system name helps you to easily identify the system that is behind the tile. To use this feature, you can enable it in the Site Manager (‚ÄúDisplay: Show Source System Name on Tiles‚Äù).

Finally, the latest release provides some nice UX enhancements, like the enhanced navigation bar for Apple iPad and a new fresher design for monitoring details on Apple Watch. When you onboard to the app for the first time, a new in-app guide introduces the app features to you. In the Profile and Settings screen, you can now find detailed information about language settings for the app and for the displayed content; furthermore the app is now available in Hungarian.

Screenshot: New watch design 

I hope you will enjoy those new features in SAP Mobile Start.

For further information on the new topics, please check our SAP Mobile Start documentation.

SAP Mobile Experience offers intelligent native mobile solutions that help businesses build more efficient, resilient and sustainable end-to-end processes, improving people‚Äôs work life wherever they are.

Visit SAP Mobile Experience Community Page and click ‚Äúfollow‚Äù to get the latest development and innovation of our solutions. We look forward to hearing about your experience with setting up the solution in your landscape; please do share your thoughts and comments below. Enter here for additional questions regarding SAP Mobile Experience Applications.

entry.title: Unsafe-eval error in SAP Build Work Zone: Understanding and fixing a CSP blockage
entry.content:
While developing a SAP Fiori application in SAP Business Application Studio (BAS), I embedded an external component within a custom SAPUI5 component. The application worked perfectly in the local development environment, but once deployed into SAP Build Work Zone (BWZ), it no longer loaded as expected.

The browser console revealed an error related to the Content Security Policy (CSP), specifically due to the indirect use of eval(). This blog post summarizes my learnings about CSP and how I resolved the issue.

What is the Content Security Policy (CSP)?

CSP is a web security standard defined by the W3C and enforced by web browsers. It allows developers to control which resources (scripts, images, styles, etc.) a browser is allowed to load and execute, helping to prevent Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attacks and malicious script injections.

For example, the following directive means that only scripts from the same origin as the application are permitted.

Content-Security-Policy: script-src 'self'

Other common directives include:

  • style-src: Specifies allowed sources for stylesheets.
  • img-src: Limits where images can be loaded from.
  • connect-src: Defines allowed sources for fetching resources like APIs.
  • default-src: Specifies a fallback for all resource types if not otherwise defined.
  • frame-ancestors: Controls which sources can embed the page in an iframe.
  • ‚Ä¶ 

To learn more about CSP, refer to the official documentation on MDN: https://developer.mozilla.org/fr/docs/Web/HTTP/CSP

Problem context

The application was developed in SAP Business Application Studio and contained an external web component wrapped inside a custom SAPUI5 component.

Once deployed to SAP Build Work Zone, the interface no longer displayed at all. The browser console then showed the following error:

Unsafe-eval error (CSP Compliant)
Uncaught (in promise) EvalError:
Refused to evaluate a string as JavaScript because 'unsafe-eval' is not an allowed source of script
in the following Content Security Policy directive: "script-src * data: blob:".

Error Meaning

In CSP, dynamic functions like eval() or new Function() are blocked by default because they can introduce serious security risks. These functions allow JavaScript code to be generated and executed at runtime, which can be exploited to inject and run malicious scripts‚Äîcommonly associated with XSS attacks.

To protect the application's security, dynamic code execution is blocked by default in the Content Security Policy (CSP). Allowing it would require the inclusion of the unsafe-eval directive in the CSP, but this weakens security and should be avoided in production environments.

Root cause analysis

In the external component I used, I was generating an HTML element returned as a string (this is where I messed up). This HTML was then dynamically injected into the component‚Äôs DOM. However, the external component was interpreting this string using new Function(), violating CSP rules.

This behavior went unnoticed locally in Business Application Studio because CSP policies are often disabled or applied more leniently in development environments. However, in SAP Build Work Zone, a strict CSP is enforced, blocking dynamic code evaluation like this.

Implemented solution

By consulting the official documentation of the component, I found that I could provide a JavaScript function directly instead of passing a returned string containing HTML. This approach enables the component to use a safe rendering function, avoiding reliance on blocked mechanisms like eval() or new Function().

Here is an example of the new CSP-compliant code:

const generateDropdown = (aOptions) => {
  // Create the select element
  const oSelectElement = document.createElement('select');
  oSelectElement.classList.add('myCustomSelectClass');

  // Loop through the options array and create option elements
  aOptions.forEach(oOption => {
    const oOptionElement = document.createElement('option');
    oOptionElement.value = oOption.value;
    oOptionElement.textContent = oOption.label;

    // Append the option to the select
    oSelectElement.appendChild(oOptionElement); 
  });

  return oSelectElement;
};

// Example usage with an array of options
const options = [
  { value: '1', label: 'Option 1' },
  { value: '2', label: 'Option 2' },
  { value: '3', label: 'Option 3' }
];

// Generate the dropdown dynamically
generateDropdown(options);

Lessons learned

An application that works correctly in BAS may encounter critical errors in BWZ if it does not comply with the CSP. It is essential to prioritize the use of real JavaScript functions over injecting HTML or JavaScript code as strings. Often, the documentation for external components provides alternative solutions that are CSP-compliant, and these should be carefully considered.

Conclusion

The Content Security Policy is an essential tool for securing web applications against XSS attacks and the execution of uncontrolled code. In environments like SAP Build Work Zone, CSP is strictly enforced, which can lead to unexpected errors.

By adapting our implementation to comply with CSP rules, we not only ensure the compatibility of our applications but also enhance their security. I hope this feedback will be useful to you.

entry.title: Build and Deploy a Full-Stack SAP CAPM App with Fiori UI on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry
entry.content:
Build and Deploy a Full-Stack SAP CAP Application with Fiori UI on BTP Cloud Foundry ‚Äì A Complete Guide.

The Cloud Application Programming (CAP) model by SAP is a robust, opinionated framework that simplifies the creation of enterprise-grade services and applications that are scalable, extensible, and cloud-ready. In this in-depth guide, we walk you through every step of building a full-stack CAP project from the ground up using SAP Business Application Studio (BAS). You'll enhance it with a Fiori UI and deploy the entire application stack to SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) on Cloud Foundry. This guide is crafted with detailed, beginner-friendly explanations and valuable insights for intermediate developers aiming to master modern SAP application development.

 ==Prerequisites and Initial Setup==

 Before we begin, ensure you have an SAP BTP trial or productive account with the necessary entitlements, including SAP HANA Cloud, SAP Build Work Zone (Standard Edition), and SAP Business Application Studio (BAS). These are essential for developing, deploying, and running CAP applications with Fiori UI on Cloud Foundry.

=== Creating a SAP HANA Cloud Instance===

To persist and manage data in your CAP application, you need to provision a SAP HANA Cloud instance in your BTP subaccount.

1.Log in to the SAP BTP Cockpit using your credentials.

2.Navigate into your global account and select the appropriate subaccount.

3.Under the navigation pane, click on "Service Marketplace" to view the available services.

4.Search for "SAP HANA Cloud" and click on it when it appears in the search results.

5.Click on the "Create" button to begin provisioning a new HANA database instance.

 

  1. Accessing SAP HANA Cloud Central
  2. Create New SAP HANA Cloud Instance

 

8.Sign-In with cloud foundry account and select your space from the dropdown

9.üîê Administrator Section

During SAP HANA Cloud instance creation, you‚Äôll need to configure administrative access:

  • Administrator Username: Pre-filled as DBADMIN (not editable)
  • Administrator Password: Enter a strong, secure password
  • Confirm Password: Re-enter the password to confirm

 

 

üîíNote: The DBADMIN password expires every 180 days. Be sure to set a reminder to update it before expiration to avoid access issues

 

10.Configure SAP HANA Database Settings

  • Available Memory Range: In the trial version, it's fixed at 16 GB.

11.SAP HANA Database Advanced Setting

üåêNetwork & Connectivity Settings

  • Allow All IP Addresses
  • Enable this option to allow unrestricted access to the database from any IP address.

üîóEnable Cloud Connector (Optional)

If your application or data sources require secure access to on-premise systems via the SAP Cloud Connector:

  • Toggle Enable Cloud Connector to ON
  • This allows secure integration between your SAP HANA Cloud instance and on-premise environments

 

12.Final Review and Create Instance

After configuring all the necessary settings ‚Äî including instance name, memory size, admin credentials, network access, and optional Cloud Connector ‚Äî take a moment to carefully:

 

  • Review the Administrator Username and Password
  • Verify Connectivity Settings (e.g., Allow All IP Addresses)
  • Confirm the Cloud Connector status (enabled or disabled)
  • Ensure there are no missing or incorrect entries

Once everything looks correct, click Create to start provisioning your SAP HANA Cloud instance.

 

‚è≥The process may take a few minutes. After successful creation, the status will change to Running ‚Äî your database is now ready for use!

 

 

  1. Steps to Manage Configuration and Instance Mapping in SAP HANA Cloud
  • Click ‚ÄúManage Configuration‚Äù:
  • Go to ‚ÄúInstance Mapping‚Äù:
  • Provide Cloud Foundry Environment Details:
  • Set the Environment to: Cloud Foundry
  • Click review and save

 

== 1. Creating a Dev Space in SAP Business Application Studio ==

  1. Open your browser and navigate to the SAP Business Application Studio.
  2. On the landing page, click on the "Create Dev Space" button, which will prompt you to select a template.
  3. From the available options, choose "Full-Stack Cloud Application" as it comes pre-configured with essential tools for CAP and Fiori development.
  4. Assign a recognizable name to your dev space, for example, capm-book-app, to easily identify it later.
  5. Check the box labeled "SAP HANA Tools" to enable support for creating and managing HANA database artifacts.
  6. Click on "Create Dev Space" and wait patiently for the status of the space to change to "RUNNING."
  7. Once the dev space is up and running, click on it to launch the integrated development environment where you will build your application.

 

2.Step-by-Step: Creating a New CAP Project from Template

  • Open SAP Business Application Studio (BAS)
  • Log in to your trial or productive BAS workspace.

2.1 Open the Command Palette

  • Click on the View menu ‚Üí Find Command
  • Or press F1 or Ctrl + Shift + P to open the Command Palette

2.3 Choose   New   Project   from Template

  • From the list, choose:  "CAP Project" (Cloud Application Programming Model)
  • Click Next

2.3 Fill Project Details

  • Project Name: e.g., bookshop
  • Choose Runtime: Node.js
  • Choose  Add  Samples   Yes (optional, useful for beginners)
  • Click  Finish

 

 

2.4 . Open in Workspace

  • If prompted: Click "Open in New Workspace"
  • The wizard will scaffold a full CAP project structure with:

== Modeling Data and Defining Services ==

  1. Define the Data Model

Create a new CDS file in the db folder, typically named data-model.cds:

 3.1 Add Sample Data in CSV Format

Create a new CSV file inside the db/data directory named my.bookshop-Books.csv:

   ID,title,stock,author

  1,The Pragmatic Programmer,42,Andrew Hunt

  2,Clean Code,37,Robert C. Martin

  3,Domain-Driven Design,15,Eric Evans

 4,Introduction to Algorithms,21,Thomas H. Cormen

 5,Design Patterns,18,Erich Gamma

 6,Refactoring,25,Martin Fowler

7,The Clean Coder,30,Robert C. Martin

8,Head First Design Patterns,40,Eric Freeman

9,Working Effectively with Legacy Code,10,Michael Feathers

10,Continuous Delivery,12,Jez Humble

                                                                  

3.2 Define a CAP Service

Inside the  srv  folder, create a service definition file named catalog-service.cds:

3.3 @odata.draft.enabled ‚Äì CAPM Annotation:

  • The @odata.draft.enabled annotation enables draft handling for an entity in SAP CAP (Cloud Application Programming Model). It supports Fiori Elements UIs by allowing users to create, update, save drafts, and finalize records without writing custom CRUD logic.
  • Adds special fields: IsActiveEntity, HasDraftEntity, HasActiveEntity.
  •  

  ‚ö†Ô∏è Notes:

¬∑       Only works with OData V4.

 

 

3.4 Steps to Add a Fiori App Using SAP Fiori Generator:

  • Click File ‚Üí New Project from Template
  • Select ‚ÄúSAP Fiori Application‚Äù and click Start
  •  Select ‚ÄúSAP Fiori Elements‚Äù

3.5 selecting the List Report Page template is a great choice for generating a powerful UI automatically from your CAP service.

  • The List Report Page is part of Fiori Elements, used to create a master-detail UI where

 

3.6 Choose Data Source and service selection :

  • If your CAP project is open in the same workspace
  • Use a local CAP project
  • Select Main Service Entity

 

3.7 After UI setup is finished:

Install dependencies
In your project root directory, run:

  •   npm install

 3.8 Start the CAP server with watch mode
Run:

  •     cds watch
  •   Starts your CAP service locally
  •  Automatically reloads when you make changes to .Cds, .js, or .json files

== 4. Configuring for SAP HANA and cloud foundary Deployment ==

CAP defaults to SQLite for local development, but to deploy on SAP BTP, you must configure it to use SAP HANA.

4.1  Add HANA configuration for production:

4.2  Adds XSUAA (SAP Authorization and Trust Management) to your project

  • Adding oauth2-configuration to xs-security.json for Local & CF Integration
  • Purpose Defines allowed callback URLs for authentication Allows redirect after deployment to Cloud Foundry (US10 region).

4.3 Add HTML5 Repo to Your Project:

  1. Adds configuration to support deploying UI modules (React, Fiori

  1. Updates the mta.yaml file to include:
  • html5-repo-host
  • html5-repo-runtime

 Enables deployment to SAP Launchpad / Work Zone or directly via managed app router

4.4 Adds an App Router to your CAP project for production deployment on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry.

1. The Application Router (Approuter) is a Node.js-based component that.

2.Routes requests to your CAP services (srv) and HTML5 apps (app).

3.Once deployed, the App Router becomes the single entry point URL for your entire application.

4.5 Adds mta.yaml file to your CAP project to enable deployment to SAP BTP Cloud Foundry using the Multi-Target Application (MTA) approach.

  • Creates the deployment descriptor required by Cloud Foundry
  • Combines your DB, service, UI, XSUAA, and HTML5 repo into one .mtar file
  • Manages Dependencies Links services like HANA, XSUAA, Approuter, and HTML5 apps together in one file.

  • Modules ‚Äî what your app is made of
  • These are the individual deployable components (e.g., backend, UI, approuter).
  • Resources ‚Äî external services your app uses
  • These are external backing services or dependencies your modules need.

4.6 Add workzone-standard  Launch your CAP app via a tile on SAP Work Zone standard edition

  • Adds a Work Zone module to your mta.yaml
  • This prepares the app for deployment to Work Zone.
  • Generates a manifest.json for Work Zone
  • Used to register the application (title, URL, etc.).

 

4.7 Install all necessary project dependencies:

4.8 Add Multi-Target Application Builder It comes from the SAP MTA SDK and builds all modules and combines them into a single .mtar file.

4.9 Deploy MTAR Archive to Cloud Foundry

  • The "Build and Deploy Completed" pop-up message appears after you build and deploy your CAPM or MTA project using SAP Business Application Studio or the CLI.

4.10 After deploying your MTA (.mtar) to Cloud Foundry, the application URL(s) become available in the Cloud Foundry space where you deployed.

 

 

Navigate to Your Destination in BTP Cockpit

  • View Your Configured Destinations
  • Test the destination (click on it ‚Üí press "Check Connection")
  • Edit credentials, token URL, client ID/secret

4.11 After deploying an HTML5 application (like a Fiori or React app) to SAP BTP (Cloud Foundry) using html5-repo, the application URL becomes available

 

4.12 Access Your Deployed HDI Container in HANA Database Explorer:

  • In HANA Cloud Central, select your HANA DB instance
  • Click "Open in SAP HANA Database Explorer"
  • Open Database Explorer Add and open your HDI container Explore your tables and data.
  •  Add Your HDI Container
  • In Database Explorer, click the + icon in the left panel (next to ‚ÄúFilter Instances‚Äù)
  • Select:
  • Your Subaccount
  • Cloud Foundry Space
  • Your deployed HDI container (e.g., bookshop_app-db_hdi-container)
  • Click OK
  • Now your HDI container will appear in the left sidebar.

 

 

  • Open and Explore Tables
  • Click on "Tables"
  • Locate your table, e.g., MY_BOOKSHOP_BOOKS
  •  Right-click or double-click the table ‚Üí Open Data

 

Conclusion:

   You now have a fully working SAP BTP full-stack application using CAPM + Fiori UI deployed on Cloud Foundry.

   Feel free to comment or reach out if you need help or enhancements.

entry.title: My AI Experience Sharing - Setting up Joule for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (C: Deinstall)
entry.content:
Introduction

Now Artificial Intelligence (AI) is on every professional‚Äôs mind. Everybody wants to be on the bandwagon.  I plan to write a series of blogs on this topic under a big umbrella ‚ÄúMy AI Experience Sharing‚Äù.  This is the first mini-series: setting up Joule for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. 

I purposely delayed my action on setting up a Joule to wait for the dust settling down during the Early Adopter phase. The intention paid off but still won‚Äôt give me a free pass üòâ. There are five credible references available as listed in the Reference section, but none of them give you a good explanation on Why, especially on What in a critical step with a readable picture when you desperately need a hint.  To help all the people like me, this blog will focus on explaining those steps, what to enter, and possible mistakes to avoid. 

Note 1: The content here is drawn from my direct experience from setting up Joule for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (more than five times and still counting). It might be true for other SAP solutions but only use that as a reference so that I don‚Äôt feel the pressure of entire SAP world on my shoulder üòÅ.

Note 2: Since there are a lot of topics to discuss, I divided the mini-series into Part A Preparation,  Part B Joule Installation and Part C Deinstallation. 

Note 3: The systems I used in this mini-series are:

  • BTP Global Account: 2024-09 3SL Account
  • BTP Joule Subaccount: PSCC-AMER-3SL-PRD
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Production tenant G4X/100, http://myxxxxxxx.s4hana.cloud.sap/ 
  • Cloud Identity Services: Provisioned together with above BTP and Public Cloud tenants, xxxxxxxx.accounts.ondemand.com

Note 4: Considering some customers and consultants need to deinstall and reinstall Joule for many reasons like practicing the installation, correcting an unsuccessful installation, etc., I am adding a new blog Part C: Deinstallation here for your reference.

 

Thirteen Major Joule Deinstallation Steps

Deinstallation is relatively easy. I list these steps in the below figure so that you can cleanly remove all the components in three systems, namely the Business Technology Platform (BTP), the S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (S/4) and the Cloud Identity Services (CIS).

Thirteen Steps to Remove Joule Installations

 

References

  1. Blog 1: Joule ‚Äì End-to-End Setup Guide (for all Line of Business) Unified Approach
  2. Blog 2: Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Setup Guide
  3. Discovery Center 1: Establish a Unified Joule Instance
  4. Discovery Center 2: Activate Joule with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  5. SAP Help: Joule onboarding guide
  6. My Blog: My AI Experience Sharing ‚Äì Setting up Joule for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Part A Preparation)
  7. My Blog: My AI Experience Sharing ‚Äì Setting up Joule for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Part B Joule Installation)
  8. My Blog: My AI Experience Sharing ‚Äì Setting up Joule for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Part C Joule Deinstallation)

entry.title: Application Frontend Service now generally available in SAP BTP Trail Account [cf us10-XXX]
entry.content:
As part of our exciting  SAP Build release, we're happy to announce the release of Application Frontend service, a new SaaS application on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) Trail account for US region for hosting, serving and operating frontend applications.

SAP BTP Trial accounts can be deployed with limited to five(5) applications per subaccount.

Now, you can enjoy the following benefits of Application Frontend Service

What is Application Frontend Service?

Host, serve, and manage frontend applications to extend SAP business solutions.

Application Frontend service lets you host and serve frontend applications. It serves as a single entry point for hosting web-based UI applications to extend SAP's business solutions. The service provides tools for deploying and managing applications, serving static resources, routing backend calls to defined targets, and observability tools.

Application Frontend service is included in the SAP Build.

Application Frontend service supports various channels for managing applications, such as the commonly used Generic Application Content Deployer (GACD) for multitarget applications (MTA), a dedicated UI in the cockpit, and a CLI. These options allow you to choose the channel that best suits your needs.

Application Frontend is a SaaS application which is not coupled to any specific SAP BTP runtime environment or other SAP BTP applications. You can find and subscribe to the service from the SAP BTP cockpit. Application Frontend is also equipped with a service broker to support interaction flows using service instances, for example when using MTA deploy in the CF environment. 

While there is native support in the good old MTA concept for lifecycle management, Application Frontend also provides a command line interface (CLI) as a first-class tool for managing your applications. With the CLI, you can directly interact with the service and execute all actions supported by Application Frontend to enjoy fast response times and new integration opportunities.

High Level Overview of Application Frontend Service - Deployment

Prerequisites to enable Application Frontend Serivce

  • Go to your SAP BTP Trail Account - Subaccount
  • Go to your Instance and Subscription - Subscribe for SAP Cloud Identity Services
  • Enable SAP IAS and Trust & Auth with enabled SAP IAS
  • Go to Entitlements - Select Application Frontend Service
  • Select 2 checkbox for enabling the Plan (Developer and Application) 
  • Create a Role Collections and Assign to your User (SAP IAS enabled)

Go to Instances and Subscription - Select Application Frontend Service from dropdown with Plan - Trial

Go to Instances and Subscription - Select Application Frontend Service with Plan - Developer

Create a New Role Collection

Assign Role to newly created Role Collection

Application Frontend Service Library & CLI (Command Line)

npm install -g /appfront-cli

afctl login --sso -a <api_endpoint>

afctl push

 

Conclusion

Application Frontend Service is a game-changer for Cloud Foundry users. By simplifying UI development, enhancing scalability, and promoting consistency, AFS empowers developers to create high-quality applications more efficiently. As cloud-native development continues to evolve, integrating tools like AFS will be crucial in staying ahead of the curve and delivering exceptional user experiences.

For more detailed insights, you can check out the original blog posts : 

  • Introducing Application Frontend Service : Application Frontend Service 
  • Simple UI Applications with Application Frontend Service : DEV Community
  • Application Frontend Service Help Documentation : Guide and Development
  • Application Frontend Service Onboarding Service -  AppFront trial on-boarding help page

entry.title: A Comprehensive Guide to Transition from SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition to advanced edition
entry.content:
As organizations evolve, the need for more integrated digital workplace solutions becomes paramount. SAP Build Work Zone offers two distinct editions to cater to varying organizational needs: the standard edition and the advanced edition. While the standard edition provides a centralized access point to multiple SAP systems, the advanced edition extends these capabilities by empowering business users. This guide aims to facilitate a seamless transition from the standard to the advanced edition, ensuring that your organization can fully harness the enhanced features of the advanced edition.

Understanding the Differences

Before embarking on the transition, it's essential to comprehend the key distinctions between the two editions to make the most of the expanded set of capabilities in advanced:

  • SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition: Formerly known as SAP Launchpad service, this edition provides a central access point to multiple SAP cloud and on-premise applications, processes & tasks via different ‚Äòapplication site‚Äô. It also offers different customization and extension capabilities. 

SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition extends the capabilities of the standard edition by empowering business users to create, manage, and publish their own content. It also offers a broader set of widgets for more flexible workpage building. Users can also create interactive communities, known as workspaces, with document access, discussion forums, knowledge base, task collaboration & more.

The following visual offers a more detailed comparison, expanded feature set of the SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition. 

Subscription and Service Plan differences

  • SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition is often bundled with certain SAP cloud solutions (such as SAP S/4HANA Cloud), providing a streamlined setup for foundational portal and page-building use cases. It supports both subscription-based and consumption-based licensing models, making it suitable for customers seeking fast onboarding with minimal complexity. You can find more details here.
  • On the other hand, SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition is a standalone, premium offering that unlocks enterprise-grade capabilities. It requires a separate license and subscription that follows a follows a consumption-based commercial model. Read more here.

Transition Steps

Transitioning from the standard to the advanced edition involves several critical steps: 

1. Assess current implementation

Begin by thoroughly evaluating your existing SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition setup. Document all active sites, pages, applications, and integrations. Identify any custom developments, branding elements, or specific configurations that are crucial for replication or adaptation in the advanced edition.

2. Plan the transition

Establish clear objectives for the transition, such as enhancing user engagement or improving content management. Engage key stakeholders, including IT teams, business users, and content creators, to gather requirements and address potential concerns.

3. Exporting content from standard edition

It's crucial to export your existing content from standard edition to facilitate a smooth transition to the advanced edition. In the Site Directory, select the desired site, click on 'More Options', and choose 'Export Site' to download the site and its content as a ZIP file. This export includes the site's structure, pages, and associated applications, ensuring that essential components are preserved for import into the advanced edition.

4. Set up the advanced edition environment

It is possible to subscribe to both SAP Build Work Zone, standard and advanced editions within the same subaccount. This makes it easier to set up the advanced edition without disrupting your current standard edition setup.

To get started, subscribe to SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition through the SAP BTP Cockpit. Configure user authentication and provisioning using SAP Cloud Identity Services (Identity Authentication and Identity Provisioning) to ensure secure and efficient user management.

Use the SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition booster to automate many of the initial setup steps in your subaccount. In addition to the booster, advanced edition requires a set of 'configurator' steps to be completed. These are essential for enabling full functionality of the service (and are not required or present in the standard edition). These steps typically include setting up roles, permissions, and other advanced configurations tailored to the edition‚Äôs extended capabilities.

5. Content migration

Since there is no fully automated upgrade or migration flow from the standard to the advanced edition, manual intervention is required. To ease the transition, you can export most of the content from the standard edition and import it into the advanced edition. This process involves the following steps:

  • Exporting the necessary content from the standard edition (as described above)
  • Importing the content to advanced edition

This approach allows for optimization and restructuring where needed. Additionally, leveraging the advanced edition's capabilities, such as interactive workspaces and enhanced page-building tools, can enrich the user experience.

6. Reusing existing configurations

When subscribing to the advanced edition within the same subaccount, certain configurations can be seamlessly reused. BTP destinations, Cloud Connector configurations, and custom applications remain intact and do not require (full) reconfiguration.

If your organization utilizes a custom domain, this can significantly ease the transition from a user perspective. For example, a custom domain that previously pointed to your standard edition site can now be reconfigured to point to the new advanced edition site. This allows users to continue accessing the Work Zone through their existing bookmarks and saved links without disruption. It ensures continuity and minimizes confusion during the switch, while maintaining consistent access points throughout the transition.

7. Best practices

To ensure a smooth transition it's advisable to first perform all migration and configuration activities in a non-production environment, such as a development or testing subaccount. This approach allows for thorough testing, validation of configurations, and identification of potential issues without impacting the live production environment. Once the transition process has been successfully tested and refined in these lower environments, you can confidently replicate the steps in the production subaccount, minimizing the risk of disruptions to end-users.

8. Testing and validation

Conduct thorough User Acceptance Testing (UAT) with a group of end-users to ensure all functionalities work as intended and meet business requirements. Evaluate the system's performance under typical load conditions to identify and address any potential issues.

9. Change management

Develop and deliver training sessions to familiarize users with the new features and interfaces of the advanced edition. Provide documentation, FAQs, and support channels to assist users during the transition period.

10. Go-live

Execute the transition plan, ensuring minimal disruption to daily operations. Continuously monitor the system for any issues and gather user feedback to make necessary adjustments.

Conclusion

This transition can significantly enhance your organization's digital workplace capabilities. By following a structured approach and leveraging the advanced features, you can create a more engaging and efficient user experience. It can empower your teams with the tools they need to collaborate effectively and drive business success.

Hope this blogpost will support your transition journey. We‚Äôll be following up shortly with a detailed how-to guide to help you through the process. 

For more detailed information consider exploring the following:

  • SAP Help Portal: Getting Started with SAP Build Work Zone
  • SAP Build Work Zone on: sap.com / SAP Community
  • SAP Learning Journeys:  Implement and Administer SAP Build Work Zone

entry.title: SAP Fiori Deployment in 2025: Embedded vs. Work Zone Standard vs. Advanced Edition
entry.content:
As SAP advances its strategy toward a unified and intelligent user experience, organizations are increasingly required to re-evaluate their SAP Fiori deployment models. Traditional architectures, such as the Central Hub, are being phased out in favor of more modern, cloud-based solutions like SAP Build Work Zone‚Äîavailable in both Standard and Advanced editions.

This shift presents a strategic decision point for IT leaders: selecting the most appropriate deployment model that aligns with their existing system landscape, integration needs, and long-term digital goals. Understanding the strengths and trade-offs of Embedded Fiori, Work Zone Standard, and Work Zone Advanced is essential for designing a scalable and user-centric enterprise environment.

This guide compares all three modern deployment approaches so you can make an informed, future-proof decision.

Option 1: Embedded Deployment (Frontend + Backend in S/4HANA)

What it is: Fiori frontend server and Launchpad are embedded directly into the SAP S/4HANA system.

Best for:

  • Greenfield S/4HANA implementations
  • Simpler landscapes with no need to federate apps from multiple sources

Pros:

  • Simplified architecture
  • Lower total cost of ownership
  • Direct and efficient performance
  • No additional BTP subscription needed

Cons:

  • Not ideal for hybrid system landscapes (e.g., ECC + S/4)
  • Downtime impacts entire stack
  • Limited flexibility for UI extensions or content aggregation

Option 2: SAP Build Work Zone, Standard Edition
(Successor to Central Hub deployment)

What it is: A cloud-based launchpad-as-a-service running on SAP BTP. Provides centralized access to apps and content from multiple SAP systems.

Best for:

  • Customers with hybrid environments (e.g., ECC, S/4HANA, CRM)
  • Users needing a unified Launchpad across systems

Pros:

  • Aggregates apps from multiple systems
  • Personalizable Launchpad (cards, themes, roles)
  • Prebuilt integration with SAP apps like Ariba, SuccessFactors, and Concur
  • Low-code extensibility with SAP Build tools
  • Lower entry point than Advanced edition

Cons:

  • Limited support for advanced workflows or custom page layouts
  • Less extensibility for 3rd-party or custom content
  • No native document management or microsite capabilities

Option 3: SAP Build Work Zone, Advanced Edition
(For full digital experience and enterprise portal replacement)

What it is: An enterprise-grade digital workplace platform built on SAP BTP + SAP Launchpad + SAP Work Zone + SAP Build Pages + SAP Knowledge Base. It replaces traditional SAP Enterprise Portal and delivers full-scale intranet functionality.

Best for:

  • Customers replacing SAP Enterprise Portal
  • Organizations needing to integrate SAP and non-SAP apps
  • Use cases requiring business content, collaboration, workflows, and knowledge-sharing

Pros:

  • Advanced page builder for intranet-like UX
  • Deep integration with Microsoft 365, Teams, SharePoint, and 3rd-party systems
  • Role-based content delivery with custom navigation layouts
  • Embedded SAP Task Center, Process Automation, Knowledge Base
  • Ideal for large, multi-LOB organizations

Cons:

  • Higher cost and complexity than Standard edition
  • Requires thoughtful implementation planning
  • Best suited for organizations with mature digital transformation goals

Comparison table:

 

DeploymentOn S/4HANA systemSAP BTPSAP BTP
System Scope1 system (S/4HANA)Multiple SAP systemsSAP + 3rd-party apps
UX FlexibilityBasic LaunchpadLaunchpad + basic cardsFull page editor, custom layouts
CollaborationNoneNonewikis, forums, Teams
Document ManagementNoneNoneAvailable
Task Center / WorkflowBasic InboxFederated InboxEmbedded SAP Task Center
M365 IntegrationNoneNoneAvailable
Use Case FitSimplicity & speedCentral accessFull digital workplace
Ideal ForS/4HANA-only landscapesHybrid SAP appsPortal replacement + collaboration
CostNo additional BTP costMediumHigher

Conclusion

Establishing a unified point of entry for enterprise users is essential to an effective SAP Fiori deployment strategy. Whether an organization operates within a single SAP S/4HANA system or manages a complex, multi-system landscape, selecting the appropriate deployment model ensures enhanced usability, simplified maintenance, and long-term adaptability.

Embedded Fiori is best suited for organizations running a clean, standalone SAP S/4HANA environment.
